datafield.subfield: The Washington Navy Yard was established in 1799 and is one of the Navy’s oldest shore establishments. The Yard was the Navy’s largest shipbuilding facility until the British burned it during the War of 1812. After the war the Yard never regained its prominence as a shipbuilding facility due to the shallow waters of the Anacostia River. In 1866 the Yard was designated as an ordnance manufacturing center and by the start of World War II it was the largest ordnance facility in the world. At its peak the Navy Yard consisted of 188 buildings on 126 acres and employed over 25,000 people. In 1964 the Yard was redesignated. Today the Yard houses a variety of activities, serving as the headquarters of the Naval District Washington, Naval Historical Center and Museum, and the home of numerous support activities for the fleet and aviation communities.
There is no deed of gift and it is uncertain as to how the library acquired these photographs.

The collection consists of thirty-one 3.5x5 and thirty 8x10 images of buildings 137 (General Foundry) and 167 (Boiler Makers shop) in the Washington Naval Yard complex. The smaller images are interior and exterior views of buildings, while the 8x10 images are reproductions of architectural blueprints. From the automobiles in the pictures it appears that the images were taken around 1975.
